quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 10 Quiz 4
quiz.subtitle: 10.4: Bond Enthalpy
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Bond energy calculations and average bond enthalpies

questions.question: Which of the following statements best describes 'Bond Enthalpy'?
options: The energy required to break one mole of a specific bond in the gaseous state.
The energy released when a solid crystal lattice forms from ions.
The energy required to melt one mole of a substance at its melting point.
The total internal energy of a molecule at absolute zero.
questions.explanation: Bond enthalpy (or bond dissociation energy) is always defined for gaseous species and refers to the energy required to overcome the attraction between atoms.

questions.question: Is bond breaking an exothermic or endothermic process?
options: It depends on the electronegativity of the atoms.
It is always zero for covalent bonds.
questions.explanation: Breaking a bond always requires an input of energy to pull the atoms apart, making it an endothermic process.

questions.question: Which formula is used to estimate the enthalpy of a reaction ($\Delta H_{rxn}$) using bond enthalpies?
options: $\Delta H_{rxn} = \sum(Bond\ enthalpies\ of\ reactants) - \sum(Bond\ enthalpies\ of\ products)$
$\Delta H_{rxn} = \sum(Bond\ enthalpies\ of\ products) - \sum(Bond\ enthalpies\ of\ reactants)$
$\Delta H_{rxn} = \sum(Bond\ enthalpies\ of\ reactants) + \sum(Bond\ enthalpies\ of\ products)$
questions.explanation: Unlike enthalpies of formation, when using bond enthalpies, we calculate 'broken minus formed' (Reactants minus Products).

questions.question: Why are calculations using 'average bond enthalpies' often slightly different from experimentally determined $\Delta H$ values?
options: Average bond enthalpies are derived from many different compounds and ignore specific molecular environments.
Average bond enthalpies ignore the state of the substance (solid/liquid/gas).
Bond enthalpies only apply to ionic compounds.
Experimental values are always wrong due to heat loss.
questions.explanation: The strength of a $C-H$ bond can vary slightly depending on the rest of the molecule; an 'average' is just a generalized estimate.

questions.question: Which of the following bonds is expected to have the highest bond enthalpy?
options: All $C-C$ bonds have the same enthalpy.
questions.explanation: Triple bonds share more electrons and have a shorter bond length, requiring significantly more energy to break than double or single bonds.

questions.question: If the energy released during bond formation is greater than the energy required for bond breaking, the reaction is:
questions.explanation: A net release of energy (products more stable than reactants) results in an exothermic reaction.

questions.question: In the reaction $H_{2}(g) + Cl_{2}(g) \rightarrow 2HCl(g)$, which bonds must be broken?
options: No bonds are broken in this reaction.
questions.explanation: Reactants must be broken into atoms before they can rearrange; here, the $H-H$ and $Cl-Cl$ single bonds are broken.

questions.question: As bond length decreases, what generally happens to the bond enthalpy?
questions.explanation: Shorter bonds typically indicate a stronger electrostatic attraction between the nuclei and the shared electrons, requiring more energy to break.

questions.question: Which of the following is required for a bond enthalpy value to be valid in a calculation?
options: All species must be in the gaseous state.
All species must be at 0 K.
The reaction must involve a metal catalyst.
The atoms must have the same electronegativity.
questions.explanation: Bond enthalpy is defined specifically for the gas phase to avoid complications from intermolecular forces like those in liquids or solids.

questions.question: Calculate $\Delta H$ for $H_{2} + F_{2} \rightarrow 2HF$ given: $H-H = 436$, $F-F = 158$, $H-F = 565$ (all in kJ/mol).

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You can calculate reaction energies using bond data with precision.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. You understand the 'broken minus formed' concept.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Remember that bond breaking is always endothermic.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on the relationship between bond strength and bond length.
